article.title: Berthe_Morisot
article.paragraph:
Infobox artistBerthe Morisot
Madame Eugène Manet Berthe Morisot, 1875.jpg 270px Berthe Morisot, 1875 Berthe Marie Pauline Morisot {{birth date|1841|1|14|mf[[Bourges]], [[Cher (département)|Cher]], [[France]] [[Eugène Manet]] {{death date and age|1895|3|2|1841|1|14|mf[[Paris]], France [[France|French]] [[Painting]]
[[Impressionism]]
Berthe Marie Pauline Morisot(IPA-frmɔʁizolang; January 14, 1841 – March 2, 1895) was aPaintingpainterand a member of the circle of painters inPariswho became known as theImpressionists. She was described byGustave Geffroyin 1894 as one of "les trois grandes dames" of Impressionism alongsideMarie BracquemondandMary Cassatt.CitationGeffroyGustaveHistoire de l'ImpressionnismeLa Vie artistique2681894.

In 1864, she exhibited for the first time in the highly esteemedParis SalonSalon de Paris. Sponsored by the government, and judged byAcademicians, the Salon was the official, annualart exhibitionexhibitionof theAcadmie des beaux-artsin Paris. Her work was selected for exhibition in six subsequent SalonsDenvir, 2000, pp. 29-79.until, in 1874, she joined the"rejected"Impressionists in the first of their own exhibitions, which includedPaul Czanne,Edgar Degas,Claude Monet,Camille Pissarro,Pierre-Auguste Renoir, andAlfred Sisley. It was held at thestudioof thephotographerNadar (photographer)Nadar.
She was married toEugne Manet, the brother of her friend and colleaguedouard Manet.
article.heading: Early life and education

link.target: File:The Mother and Sister of the Artist.JPG
link.part: Berthe Morisot, ''Portrait de Mme Morisot et de sa fille Mme Pontillon ou La lecture'' (The Mother and Sister of the Artist - Marie-Josphine & Edma) 1869/70

article.paragraph: Morisot was born inBourges, France, into an affluent bourgeois family. Her father, Edm Tiburce Morisot, was theprefect(senior administrator) of theDepartments of FrancedepartmentofCher (dpartement)Cher. Her mother, Marie-Josphine-Cornlie Thomas, was the great-niece ofJean-Honor Fragonard, one of the most prolificRococopainters of theancien rgime.Higonnet, p. 5She had two older sisters, Yves (18381893) and Edma (18391921), plus a younger brother, Tiburce, born in 1848. The family moved to Paris in 1852, when Morisot was a child.

It was common practice for daughters of bourgeois families to receive art education, so Berthe and her sisters Yves and Edma were taught privately by Geoffroy-Alphonse Chocarne and:fr:Joseph GuichardJoseph Guichard. In 1857 Guichard introduced Berthe and Edma to theLouvregallery where they could learn by looking, and from 1858 they learned by copying paintings. He also introduced them to the works ofGavarni.

As art students, Berthe and Edma worked closely together until Edma married Adolphe Pontillon, a naval officer, moved toCherbourg, had children, and had less time to paint. Letters between the sisters show a loving relationship, underscored by Berthe's regret at the distance between them and Edma's withdrawal from painting. Edma wholeheartedly supported Berthe's continued work and their families always remained close. Edma wroteI am often with you in thought, dear Berthe. Im in your studio and I like to slip away, if only for a quarter of an hour, to breathe that atmosphere that we shared for many years.Women in the Act of Painting, 9 November 2012, Edma and Berthe by Nancy Bea Miller

Her sister Yves married Theodore Gobillard, a tax inspector, in 1866, and was painted byEdgar DegasasMrs Theodore Gobillard(Metropolitan Museum of Art,New York).Yves peinte par DegasharvspStuckey et al16SSL87''Berthe Morisot'' by Anne Higonnet, Berthe Morisot, at Google Books. Page 32

Morisot registered as acopyistat the Louvre where she befriended other artists and teachers includingCamille Corot, the pivotal landscape painter of theBarbizon Schoolwho also excelled in figure painting. In 1860, under Corot's influence she took up theplein air(outdoors) method of working. By 1863 she was studying under:fr:Achille OudinotAchille Oudinot, another Barbizon painter. In the winter of 186364 she studied sculpture underAim Millet, but none of her sculpture is known to survive.cite bookHigonnetAnneBerthe Morisot1990Harper & Row, PublishersNew York0-06-016232-511–25
article.heading: Impressionism
article.paragraph: Morisot's first appearance in theSalon (Paris)Salon de Pariscame at the age of twenty-three in 1864, with the acceptance of twolandscape artlandscapepaintings. She continued to show regularly in the Salon, to generally favorable reviews, until 1873, the year before the first Impressionist exhibition. She exhibited with the Impressionists from 1874 onwards, only missing the exhibition in 1878 when her daughter was born.cite bookChadwickWhitneyWomen, Art, and Society2012Thames & Hudson Inc.London978-0-500-20405-4253Fifth

Morisot's mature career began in 1872. She found an audience for her work withDurand-Ruel, the private dealer, who bought twenty-two paintings. In 1877, she was described by the critic forLe Tempsas the "one real Impressionist in this group."cite bookChadwickWhitneyWomen, Art, and Society2012Thames & Hudson Ltd.London978-0-500-20405-42345thShe chose to exhibit under her full maiden name instead of using a pseudonym or her married name.cite bookHigonnetAnneBerthe Morisot1990Harper & Row, Publishers, Inc.New York0-06-016232-5139In the 1880 exhibition, many reviews judged Morisot among the best, includingLe FigarocriticAlbert Wolff (journalist)Albert Wolff.cite bookHigonnetAnneBerthe Morisot1990Harper & Row, Publishers, Inc.New York0-06-016232-5158
article.heading: Exhibitions

list.listitem: 1864 exhibited two paintings in the Paris Salon
1874 first Impressionist exhibition, showed twelve works
1875 Auction at Hotel Drouot, showed twelve works
1880 Paris exhibition, reviews judged her among the best.
1883 London exhibition, organized by Durand-Ruel including three works by Morisot
1892 first solo-exhibition of forty-three works in Paris by Boussod and Valadon

article.heading: Manet
article.paragraph: File:Edouard Manet - Berthe Morisot With a Bouquet of Violets - Google Art Project.jpgthumbdouard Manet, ''Berthe Morisot with a Bouquet of Violets'' (in mourning for her father), 1872,Muse d'OrsayIn 1868 Morisot became friends withdouard Manetwho painted several portraits of her, including a striking study in a black veil while in mourning for her father. Correspondence between them shows warm affection, and Manet gave her an easel as a Christmas present. To her dismay he interfered with one of her Salon submissions whilst he was engaged to transport it, mistaking her self-criticism as an invitation to add corrections.

Although Manet is regarded as the master and Morisot as the follower, there is evidence that their relationship was reciprocal.Turner, 2000, p. 319.Records show Manet's appreciation of her distinctive original style and compositional decisions, some of which he incorporated into his own work. It was Morisot who persuaded Manet to attemptplein airpainting, which she had been practising since having been introduced to it by Corot.cite webhttp://www.paulvanrensburg.com/morisot.htmlBerthe Morisot (1841-1895)Paul van Rensburg Gallery of Art

Morisot drew Manet into the circle of painters who became known as the Impressionists. In 1874, she married Manet's brother, Eugne, and they had one daughter,Julie ManetJulie, who became the subject for many of her mother's paintings. Julie's memoirs,Growing Up with the Impressionists: The Diary of Julie Manet, were published in 1987.
article.heading: Style and technique
article.paragraph: Morisots works are almost always small in scale. She worked in oil paint, watercolors, or pastel, and sketched using various drawing media. Around 1880 she began painting on unprimed canvasesa technique Manet andEva Gonzalsalso experimented with at the timeNational Museum of Women in the Arts: "The Cage", retrieved November 24, 2014.and her brushwork became looser. In 188889, her brushstrokes transitioned from short, rapid strokes to long, sinuous ones that define form.cite bookMonganElizabethBerthe Morisot, Drawings Pastels, Watercolors1960Shorewood Publishing Co.New York20The outer edges of her paintings were often left unfinished, allowing the canvas to show through and increasing the sense of spontaneity. After 1885, she worked mostly from preliminary drawings before beginning her oil paintings.cite bookStuckeyCharles F.ScottWilliam P.Berthe Morisot: Impressionist1987Hudson Hills PressNew York0-933920-03-2187–207

Morisot creates a sense of space and depth through the use of color. Although her color palette was somewhat limited, her fellow impressionists regarded her as a "virtuoso colorist".She typically made expansive use of white, whether used as a pure white or mixed with other colors. In her large painting,The Cherry Tree, colors are more vivid but are still used to emphasize form.
article.heading: Subjects
article.paragraph: File:Berthe Morisot - Bergre nue couche.jpgthumb''Bergre nue couche'' (Shepherdess - reclining nude) by Berthe MorisotFile:Morisot TheArtistsDaughterJulieWithHerNanny MIA 9640.jpgthumbBerthe Morisot, ''The Artist's Daughter Julie with her Nanny,'' c. 1884.Minneapolis Institute of ArtMorisot painted what she experienced on a daily basis. Her paintings reflect the 19th-century cultural restrictions of her class and gender. She avoided urban and street scenes and seldom painted the nude figure. Like her fellow ImpressionistMary Cassatt, she focused on domestic life and portraits in which she could use family and personal friends as models, including her daughter Julie. Prior to the 1860s, Morisot painted subjects in line with the Barbizon school before turning to scenes of contemporary femininity.cite bookHigonnetAnneBerthe Morisot1990Harper & Row, Publishers, Inc.New York0-06-016232-526Paintings likeThe Cradle(1872), in which she depicted current trends for nursery furniture, reflect her sensitivity to fashion and advertising, both of which would have been apparent to her female audience. Her works also include landscapes, portraits, garden settings and boating scenes. Later in her career Morisot worked with more ambitious themes, such as nudes.cite bookHigonnetAnneBerthe Morisot1990Harper & Row, Publishers, Inc.New York0-06-016232-5102Corresponding with Morisot's interest in nude subjects, Morisot also began to focus more on preliminary drawings, completing many drypoints, charcoal, and color pencil drawings.Cite bookBerthe Morisot ImpressionistStuckeyCharles F.Hudson Hills Press19870-933920-04-0New York126-130
article.heading: Personal life
article.paragraph: Morisot was married toEugne Manet, the brother of her friend and colleaguedouard Manet, from 1874 until his death in 1892. In 1878 she gave birth to her only child,Julie ManetJulie, who posed frequently for her mother and other Impressionist artists, including Renoir and her uncle douard.
article.heading: Death
article.paragraph: Morisot died on 2 March 1895, in Paris, ofpneumoniacontracted while attending to her daughter Julie's similar illness, and thus orphaning her at the age of 16. She was interred in theCimetire de Passy.
article.heading: Popular culture
article.paragraph: She was portrayed by actressMarine Deltermein the eponymous 2012 French biographicalTV filmdirected byCaroline Champetier. The character of Beatrice de Clerval inElizabeth Kostova'sThe Swan Thievesis largerly based on Morisot.cite webhttp://www.bookpage.com/the-book-case/2009/11/17/sneak-peek-elizabeth-kostovas-the-swan-thieves/Sneak peek: Elizabeth Kostova's 'The Swan Thieves'Trisha, Managing Editorbookpage.com17 Nov 200917 March 2012
article.heading: Art market
article.paragraph: Morisot's work sold comparatively well. She achieved the two highest prices at aHtel Drouotauction in 1875, theInterior (Young Woman with Mirror)sold for 480 francs, and her pastelOn the Lawnsold for 320 francs.cite bookChadwickWhitneyWomen, Art, and Society2012Thames & Hudson Ltd.London978-0-500-20405-42355thcite bookHigonnetAnneBerthe Morisot1990Harper & Row, Publishers, Inc.New York0-06-016232-5124Her works averaged 250 francs, the best relative prices at the auction.cite bookShennanMargaretBerthe Morisot: The First Lady of Impressionism1996Sutton Publishing LimitedStroud0-7509-1226 X173

Morisot became the highest priced female artist in February 2013, whenAfter Lunch(1881), a portrait of a young redhead in a straw hat and purple dress, sold for $10.9 million at aChristie'sauction, roughly three times its high estimate,Kelly Crow and Mary M. Lane (February 6, 2013),Christie's Breaks World Record Price for Female ArtistWall Street Journal.Ellen Gamerman and Mary M. Lane (April 18, 2013),Women on the VergeWall Street Journal.Katya Kazakina (May 14, 2014),Billionaires Help Christies to Record $745 Million SaleBloomberg L.P.Bloomberg.exceeding the $10.7 million for a sculpture byLouise Bourgeoisin 2012.
article.heading: Works
Selection of Works

listitem.italics: This list is incomplete, you can help by expanding it with certified entries.

article.paragraph: This limited selection is based on the bookBerthe Morisotby Charles F. Stuckey, William P. Scott and Susan G. Lindsay, which is in turn drawn from the 1961 catalogue by Marie-Louise Bataille, Rouaart Denis and Georges Wildenstein. There are variations between the dates of execution, first showing and purchase. Titles may vary between sources.
